title: Multiple Sclerosis - Chronic Management
scope: ** Long-term management of established MS including disease-modifying therapy (DMT) monitoring, symptom management optimization, surveillance imaging, preventive care, and special populations (pregnancy planning). Excludes acute MS relapse (see "MS - Exacerbation") and initial diagnostic workup (see "MS - New Diagnosis"). Primary focus is outpatient management with guidance for ED/hospital presentation of established MS patients.

Referrals & Consults.item: MS specialist/Neuroimmunology for annual comprehensive review and DMT optimization
Neuro-ophthalmology for visual complaints, OCT monitoring, or suspected optic neuritis
Physical therapy for gait training, balance exercises, and fall prevention given progressive mobility decline
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, energy conservation strategies, and adaptive equipment
Speech therapy for dysphagia evaluation given brainstem involvement or swallowing concerns
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing if subjective or objective cognitive decline
Cognitive rehabilitation (speech therapy or neuropsychology) for documented cognitive impairment
Urology for refractory bladder symptoms, recurrent UTIs, or urodynamic testing consideration
Psychiatry for depression, anxiety, or adjustment disorders not responding to first-line treatment
Pain management for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to multiple first-line agents
Physiatry/Rehabilitation medicine for comprehensive rehabilitation planning and spasticity management
Social work for disability planning, insurance navigation, and community resource connection
Genetic counseling if considering pregnancy with strong family history or known genetic mutations
High-risk OB for pregnancy planning discussion in women on DMTs
Infusion center for DMT administration and monitoring
Palliative care for advanced MS with significant symptom burden or goals of care discussions

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if rapid vision loss, new weakness, numbness, or difficulty walking develops (may indicate relapse requiring steroids)
Report fever or signs of infection promptly as immunomodulatory DMTs increase infection risk
Continue DMT as prescribed unless instructed otherwise by neurology - do not stop without discussing
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive DMTs (fingolimod, siponimod, cladribine, anti-CD20 therapies, alemtuzumab)
Heat may temporarily worsen symptoms (Uhthoff phenomenon) - use cooling strategies; this is NOT a new relapse
Maintain symptom diary noting new symptoms, fatigue levels, and bladder/bowel patterns
Do not stop baclofen or tizanidine abruptly - taper under medical supervision to avoid withdrawal
Report any skin changes, new moles, or suspicious lesions given increased malignancy risk with some DMTs
Women of childbearing potential: discuss pregnancy plans with MS specialist before conception given DMT-specific washout requirements
Report unusual fatigue, shortness of breath, chest pain, or palpitations if on S1P modulators (cardiac effects)
If on natalizumab: report any new neurological symptoms, especially if subtle (confusion, personality change, clumsiness) as may indicate PML
Take dalfampridine exactly 12 hours apart and never exceed 2 doses per day (seizure risk)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation - smoking accelerates MS progression, increases relapse rate, and worsens disability
Vitamin D supplementation 2000-5000 IU daily to maintain serum 25-OH vitamin D >40 ng/mL (target >50 ng/mL)
Regular aerobic exercise 150 minutes per week as tolerated - improves fatigue, mood, mobility, and may slow progression
Aquatic therapy/swimming - allows exercise with built-in cooling and reduced fall risk
Resistance training 2-3 times weekly for strength maintenance and bone health
Stress management techniques as stress may trigger pseudorelapses and worsen fatigue
Sleep hygiene - ensure 7-8 hours nightly; address sleep disorders contributing to fatigue
Avoid excessive heat exposure (hot tubs, saunas, exercising in heat) - use cooling vests for outdoor activities
Fall prevention: remove loose rugs, ensure adequate lighting, use assistive devices (cane, walker) as needed
Complete recommended vaccinations before starting immunosuppressive DMTs - inactivated vaccines safe on most DMTs
Annual influenza vaccine (inactivated) and COVID-19 vaccines per current guidelines (timing around infusions for anti-CD20)
Limit alcohol intake as it can worsen balance, cognitive symptoms, and interact with medications
Mediterranean diet pattern may have anti-inflammatory benefits based on observational data
DEXA scan for bone density monitoring if prolonged steroid exposure, immobility, or menopause

differential.tests: MRI (subcortical non-enhancing lesions); CSF JCV PCR

differential.features: Fever, meningeal signs, rapid deterioration; immunosuppressed
Sudden onset; vascular risk factors; non-MS territory
Temporal relationship to new medication or dose change
Inconsistent exam; non-anatomical patterns; psychiatric comorbidity
Progressive; dorsal column signs; may coexist with MS
Progressive; atypical pattern; on immunosuppressive DMT

disposition.criteria: Mild symptom worsening attributable to pseudorelapse (infection treated, heat exposure resolved); stable neurologic exam; able to care for self or adequate caregiver support; reliable follow-up

Moderate-severe acute relapse requiring IV steroids; functional decline preventing safe discharge; diagnostic workup for suspected PML or CNS infection; severe medication side effect requiring monitoring
Severe myelitis with respiratory compromise (NIF declining toward -20 cm H2O); brainstem involvement with airway risk; severe infusion reaction; suspected PML with rapid deterioration
PLEX needed but unavailable; MS specialist not available for complex decision-making (PML management, severe breakthrough); MRI unavailable for urgent imaging
Every 3-6 months for stable patients; q1-3 months during DMT transition or active disease; annually minimum for established stable patients
